questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not a biogenic amine?
questions.solution:
Glycine is not a biogenic amine. It is an amino acid. 

Biogenic amines are made from amino acid precursors. They have a nitrogen containing amine (NH2) group. Unlike the amino acids, the biogenic amines lack a carboxyl (COOH) group. Norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine, serotonin and histamine are biogenic amines.

questions.text: The main excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS are ______
questions.solution:
Glutamate is the main excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS. It is responsible for 75% of the excitatory transmission in the brain.

Glycine and GABA are the main inhibitory neurotransmitters in the CNS. Glycine is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord. GABA is the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain.

questions.text: 'A' delta fibers and 'C' fibers carry pain sensation. The neurotransmitter released by 'A' delta fibers is ______
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by A delta fibers, which carry sharp pricking pain, is glutamate.

The substance released by C fibers, which carry diffuse, chronic, burning pain is substance P.

questions.text: The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is ______
questions.solution:
The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is dopamine.

Reward pathway (mesolimbic pathway) connects the ventral tegmental area in the midbrain to the nucleus accumbens and limbic subcortical areas. This pathway is involved in reward behaviour, addiction and in psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia.

questions.text: Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to ______
questions.solution: Dopamine beta hydroxylase converts dopamine to norepinephrine. Vitamin C is required as a cofactor for the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of these is not a dopaminergic pathway?
questions.solution:
Corticostrial pathway is not a dopaminergic pathway.

The corticostrial pathway is the primary input pathway for the basal ganglia which uses glutamate as the neurotransmitter.

Important dopaminergic pathways are:

  • Mesolimbic pathway - Increased activity responsible for positive symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Mesocortical pathway - Decreased activity responsible for negative symptoms of schizophrenia.
  • Nigrostriatal pathway - Decreased activity causes extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Tuberoinfundibular pathway - Decreased activity causes increase in prolactin.

Basal forebrain complex (nucleus basalis of Meynert) is rich in acetylcholine. 

A loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert is seen in alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A patient with involuntary jerking and writhing movements is diagnosed with Huntington's disease. Loss of which of the following is responsible for hyperkinetic symptoms in this condition?
questions.solution:
The hyperkinetic feature of Huntington's disease is due to the loss of intrastriatal GABAergic and cholinergic neurons. The loss of the GABAergic pathway (which is an inhibitory pathway) to the globus pallidus external segment and loss of cholinergic neurons in many parts of the brain decreases inhibition, causing the hyperkinetic feature of the disease to develop.

Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder with multiple CAG repeats. The abnormal gene responsible for the disease is located on chromosome 4.

questions.text: An infant develops features of botulism following honey intake. This toxin blocks neuromuscular transmission by which of the following mechanisms?

choices.text: Prevents release of Ach at presynaptic membrane
Opening of calcium channels at the presynaptic membrane
Prevents the binding of Ach at the postsynatic membrane
Prevents the action of Ach at the postsynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin prevents the release of Ach at the presynaptic membrane.

Botulinum toxins A, B, and E are toxic to humans. They cleave components of SNARE - a complex of proteins necessary for the exocytosis of acetylcholine. Toxins A and E cleave SNAP-25 whereas toxin B cleaves vesicle-associated membrane protein (VAMP) also known as synaptobrevin.

Cleavage of SNARE proteins prevents the release of acetylcholine as the vesicles containing Ach are unable to bind to the presynaptic membrane.

questions.text: A farmer presents with difficulty swallowing and jaw tightening. He gives a history of getting his finger jammed in the rustic gate a few days ago. He gives no history of previous tetanus immunization. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with tetanus. The release of which of the following neurotransmitters is affected by the toxin responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Tetanus toxin affects the release of GABA.

Tetanus toxin escapes normal lysosomal degradation and crosses the synapse to the GABA-ergic presynaptic inhibitory interneuron terminals. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid) across the synaptic cleft. This blockage of the inhibitory neurotransmitters causes spastic paralysis.

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by  Renshaw cell interneuron is ______.
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is glycine.

Renshaw cell is an inhibitory interneuron which is activated by collaterals from spinal motor neurons. Renshaw cell terminates on the cell body of the same and other spinal motor neurons. It reduces or stops the discharge of the motor neuron by releasing glycine.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is increased during REM sleep?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine increases during REM sleep.

In REM sleep, there is increase in acetylcholine and decrease in norepinephrine and serotonin. The reverse of this pattern leads to wakefulness.

questions.text: Which of the following is the wrong match?

choices.text: Sympathetic post ganglionic fibres - release noradrenaline
Sweat glands - innervated by sympathetic adrenergic fibres

questions.solution:
Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibres (not adrenergic fibres).

Pre-ganglionic fibres of the sympathetic nervous system, pre-ganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic nervous system and post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibres release acetylcholine.

Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres release noradrenaline in most of the sites, except in certain places such as sweat glands, piloerector muscles and blood vessels in some skeletal muscles where acetylcholine is released.

questions.text: Which part of the basal ganglia is the neurotransmitter glutamate secreted from?
questions.solution:
Projections from subthalamic nucleus to globus pallidus are glutaminergic.

Neurotransmitters secreted by various regions of basal ganglia:

  • Substantia nigra pars compacta = dopamine
  • Substantia nigra pars reticulata = GABA
  • Subthalmic nuclei = glutamate
  • Corpus striatum to globus pallidus = GABA
  • Intrastriate neurons = acetylcholine
  • Globus pallidus = GABA

 

Diagrammatic representation of the principal connections of the basal ganglia. 

Acetylcholine is the transmitter produced by interneurons in the striatum.

(SNr : substantia nigra pars reticulata; SNc: substantia nigra pars compacta; STN: Subthalamic nucleus ; GPe: globus pallidus externa ; GPi: Globus pallidus interna).

questions.text: All of the following are excitatory neurotransmitters except:
questions.solution:
Serotonin is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. 

Acetylcholine, glutamate and norepinephrine are excitatory neurotransmitters.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about serotonin receptor?
questions.solution:
5-HT2C receptor agonists increase satiety (state of being fed beyond capacity).

Important serotonin receptors:

  • 5-HT2A receptors mediate platelet aggregation and smooth muscle contraction.
  • 5-HT3 receptors are present in the GIT and the area postrema and are related to vomiting.
  • 5-HT4 receptors are present in the GIT and brain. They facilitate secretion and peristalsis in GIT.
  • 5-HT6 and 5-HT7 are distributed throughout the limbic system.

Note: All are G protein coupled receptors except 5-HT3 which is a ligand gated ion channel receptor.

questions.text: Serotonin is present in highest concentration in ________
questions.solution:
Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT) is present in highest concentration in platelets and in the gastrointestinal tract, where it is found in the enterochromaffin cells and the myenteric plexus. It is also found within the brain stem in the midline Raphe nuclei.

Note: The precursor of serotonin is tryptophan.

questions.text: Which statement regarding the NMDA receptor is incorrect?

choices.text: Glycine is essential for this receptor's response to its endogenous agonist
It is a chloride ion channel
It is present in hippocampal neurons

questions.solution:
NMDA receptor permits passage of Ca2+ and other cations (Na+), not of chloride.

Glutamate is the agonist for NMDA receptor. Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essential for the receptor to respond to glutamate. NMDA receptors are present on hippocampal neurons.

Note: GABA and glycine receptors act by increasing Cl- conductance.
